ConnectorGuide.pageDescription: Find the perfect connector for your application in 5 simple steps

step1.title: What type of connection do you need?
step1.description: Select the application that best describes your project

wireToWire.title: Wire-to-Wire Connection
wireToWire.description: Connect two wire assemblies together using a socket and tab connector pair

wireToBoard.title: Wire-to-Board Connection
wireToBoard.description: Connect wire assembly to a printed circuit board using socket and PCB header

boardToBoard.title: Board-to-Board Connection
boardToBoard.description: Connect two printed circuit boards together using PCB headers

step2.title: How many circuits do you need?
step2.description: Select the number of poles (circuits/wires) for your connection

step3.title: What orientation works best?
step3.description: Choose how the connector should mount relative to your board or wire

horizontal.title: Horizontal (Parallel)
horizontal.description: Connector body is parallel to the board or wire. Best for space-constrained designs.

vertical.title: Vertical (Perpendicular)
vertical.description: Connector body is perpendicular to the board or wire. Easier cable management.

either.title: Show Both Options
either.description: Not sure? See both horizontal and vertical options to compare.

step4.title: Any special requirements?
step4.description: Optional features to refine your selection (you can skip this step)

locking.title: Locking Mechanism Required
locking.description: Ensures secure connection in high-vibration environments

specialVersion.title: Special Version (FR, VR, VS, VT, FT)
specialVersion.description: Variants with specific features like flanges or reversed orientations

keying.title: Specific Keying Requirements
keying.description: Need custom keying to prevent incorrect mating

step4.infoMessage: These are optional filters. Leave them unchecked to see all available options.

noResults.title: No Connectors Match Your Criteria
noResults.description: Try adjusting your requirements or remove optional filters

TerminalsPage.title: Terminal Components Guide
TerminalsPage.description: Complete reference for RAST 5 terminal types

hero.title: Terminal Components Guide
hero.description: Complete technical reference for RAST 5 terminal components. Learn about socket, tab, and PCB terminals, their specifications, and proper installation techniques.

overview.sectionDescription: Terminals are the conductive metal components that create the electrical connection inside RAST 5 connectors. Each connector type requires specific terminal variants.

whatAreTerminals.title: What are Terminals?
whatAreTerminals.description: Terminals are precision-formed metal contacts that crimp onto wires or mount to PCBs. They provide the physical and electrical connection between wire and connector housing.

whyDifferentTypes.title: Why Different Types?
whyDifferentTypes.description: Different orientations (vertical/horizontal), mounting types (wire/PCB), and mating styles (socket/tab) require specific terminal designs to ensure proper fit and reliable connections.

namingConvention.title: Naming Convention
namingConvention.description: Terminals are identified by suffix codes (FR, VR, VS, VT, FT, PC) which indicate the terminal type. Always match the terminal suffix to your connector requirements.

terminalTypes.sectionDescription: Explore the three main categories of RAST 5 terminals

socket.categoryDescription: Receptacle-style terminals that accept tab terminals for secure electrical connections

FR.name: Female Receptacle
FR.description: Standard female socket terminal with flat mounting orientation

VR.name: Vertical Receptacle
VR.description: Female socket terminal with vertical orientation for perpendicular connections

VS.name: Vertical Socket
VS.description: Specialized vertical socket terminal with enhanced contact area

tab.categoryDescription: Blade-style terminals that insert into socket terminals for mating connections

VT.name: Vertical Tab
VT.description: Male tab terminal with vertical blade orientation

FT.name: Flat Tab
FT.description: Male tab terminal with flat blade orientation

pcb.categoryDescription: Through-hole terminals designed for direct PCB mounting and soldering

PC.name: Printed Circuit
PC.description: Through-hole terminal for direct PCB mounting

technicalSpecs.sectionDescription: Universal specifications applicable to all RAST 5 terminal types

currentRating.title: Current Rating
currentRating.description: Maximum continuous current at 25°C ambient temperature

voltageRating.title: Voltage Rating
voltageRating.description: Maximum working voltage per IEC standards

wireRange.title: Wire Range
wireRange.description: Compatible wire gauge for crimp terminals

contactMaterial.heading: Contact Material
contactMaterial.matingArea: Mating Area: Gold flash available on request

installation.sectionDescription: Step-by-step instructions for proper terminal crimping and insertion

crimpingTool.title: Crimping Tool
crimpingTool.description: Calibrated ratcheting crimper with proper die set for RAST 5 terminals

wireStripper.title: Wire Stripper
wireStripper.description: Adjustable wire stripper for 16-22 AWG wire gauge

insertionTool.title: Insertion/Removal Tool
insertionTool.description: Special tool for terminal insertion and safe removal if needed

1.title: Strip Wire
1.description: Strip insulation to expose 5-6mm of conductor
1.warning: Do not over-strip or damage strands

2.title: Insert into Terminal
2.description: Place wire into terminal crimp area
2.warning: Ensure wire is fully inserted before crimping

3.title: Crimp Terminal
3.description: Use proper crimping tool to secure terminal
3.warning: Check crimp quality - no strand pullout

4.title: Insert into Housing
4.description: Push terminal into connector housing until it clicks
4.warning: Terminal must be fully seated and locked

5.title: Verify Lock
5.description: Gently tug wire to confirm terminal is secured
5.warning: Terminal should not pull out of housing

terminalRemoval.title: Terminal Removal Procedure
terminalRemoval.description: If you need to remove a terminal from the housing

steps.1: Use proper terminal removal tool - never force with pliers or screwdriver
steps.2: Insert removal tool alongside terminal to release locking tab
steps.3: Gently pull wire while holding removal tool in place
steps.4: Inspect terminal for damage before reuse - damaged terminals must be replaced

commonMistakes.sectionDescription: Learn from these common errors to ensure reliable connections

1.consequence: Exposed conductor creates short circuit risk

2.consequence: Poor electrical connection or damaged wire
2.solution: Use calibrated crimp tool with proper die

3.solution: Verify terminal suffix matches connector requirements

downloadResources.title: Technical Documentation
downloadResources.description: Download detailed specification sheets and installation guides

browseCatalog.title: Browse Connectors
browseCatalog.description: View our complete catalog of RAST 5 connectors

selectionGuide.title: Selection Guide
selectionGuide.description: Interactive wizard to find the right connector

hero.title: RAST 5 Connector Installation Guide
hero.subtitle: Comprehensive step-by-step instructions for professional assembly, crimping, and installation of RAST 5 connectors

items.1: Always disconnect power before working on electrical connections
items.2: Use properly rated tools and equipment for your application
items.3: Wear appropriate personal protective equipment (safety glasses, insulated gloves)
items.4: Follow all local electrical codes and regulations
items.5: If unsure, consult a qualified electrician or engineer

gettingStarted.title: Getting Started
gettingStarted.description: What you'll need and how to prepare your workspace

items.1: Clean, well-lit workspace with adequate room for tools and materials
items.2: ESD-safe mat if working with sensitive electronic components
items.3: Organize connectors, terminals, and wires by type and size
items.4: Keep this installation guide readily accessible for reference

steps.title: Step-by-Step Installation Process
steps.description: Follow these steps carefully for reliable, professional assembly

understandingTypes.title: Understanding Terminal Types
understandingTypes.description: RAST 5 connectors use different terminal types based on the connector suffix:

types.FR: FR (Flange, Right Angle) - Female terminals with flange mounting
types.FT: FT (Flange, Through-hole) - Female terminals for PCB mounting
types.VR: VR (Vertical, Right Angle) - Vertical orientation terminals
types.VS: VS (Vertical, Surface Mount) - SMT terminals for PCB

important.title: Important
important.message: Always verify terminal compatibility with your specific connector model. Using incorrect terminals can result in poor connections and potential failure.

items.1: Verify connector model and terminal suffix
items.2: Confirm wire gauge matches terminal specifications
items.3: Check current rating requirements for your application
items.4: Ensure sufficient quantity of terminals for all positions

1.title: Cut wire to required length
1.description: Add extra length for routing and strain relief (typically 50-100mm extra)

2.title: Inspect insulation
2.description: Check for nicks, cuts, or damage. Discard damaged wire.

3.title: Strip insulation
3.description: Use proper wire strippers set to correct gauge. Strip 5-6mm from end.

4.title: Inspect conductor
4.description: Ensure no strands are cut or damaged. All strands should be intact and clean.

5.title: Twist conductor (if stranded)
5.description: Gently twist stranded wire clockwise to keep strands together

items.1: Clean, straight cut
items.2: No damaged strands
items.3: Proper length (5-6mm)
items.4: No insulation nicks

items.1: Ragged or uneven cut
items.2: Cut/missing strands
items.3: Wrong length
items.4: Damaged insulation

criticalQuality.title: Critical Quality Step
criticalQuality.message: Proper crimping is essential for reliable electrical connections. A good crimp provides both electrical conductivity and mechanical strength. Take your time and inspect every crimp.

recommended.title: Recommended: RAST 5-Specific Tool
recommended.description: Purpose-built tools ensure proper crimp geometry and force

acceptable.title: Acceptable: Precision Crimping Pliers
acceptable.description: Must have correct die set for terminal size

notRecommended.title: Not Recommended: Standard Pliers
notRecommended.description: Will not provide proper crimp quality or reliability

1.title: Position terminal in crimp tool
1.description: Ensure terminal is fully seated in the correct die position

2.title: Insert prepared wire
2.description: Wire should extend fully into terminal barrel. Insulation should NOT enter crimp area.

3.title: Apply crimp force
3.description: Squeeze handles completely until tool releases (ratcheting tools) or until handles touch (non-ratcheting)

4.title: Remove crimped terminal
4.description: Carefully release tool and remove terminal without bending

5.title: Inspect crimp quality
5.description: See inspection criteria below - reject any questionable crimps

goodCrimp.title: Characteristics of a Good Crimp:

items.1: Terminal barrel is uniformly compressed around wire
items.2: Wire strands are visible at end of terminal barrel
items.3: No gaps between wire and terminal barrel walls
items.4: Insulation crimp grips wire jacket without cutting it
items.5: Wire cannot be pulled out with moderate force
items.6: Terminal contact area is undamaged and properly shaped

goodCrimp.tip: Use a magnifying glass or loupe to inspect crimp area. The barrel should show slight indentation from the crimp dies but no cracks or sharp edges.

badCrimp.title: Signs of a Bad Crimp (Reject These):

items.1: Under-crimped: Terminal barrel not fully compressed, wire pulls out easily
items.2: Over-crimped: Terminal barrel cracked, cut wire strands, or damaged contact
items.3: Misaligned: Wire not fully inserted, strands visible outside barrel
items.4: Insulation in crimp area: Wire jacket crimped into conductor area
items.5: Bent or damaged terminal contact area
items.6: Visible cracks or splits in terminal barrel

badCrimp.warning: When in doubt, cut off the terminal and re-crimp with a new terminal. Bad crimps can cause intermittent connections, increased resistance, heat generation, and eventual failure.

pullTest.title: Pull Test (Optional but Recommended)
pullTest.description: After crimping, perform a gentle pull test to verify mechanical integrity:

steps.3: 3. Pull with moderate force (approximately 5-10 lbs / 2-5 kg)
steps.4: 4. Wire should not pull out or show any movement in terminal barrel

orientationVerification.title: Orientation Verification
orientationVerification.description: Before inserting terminals, verify correct orientation:

items.1: Terminal contact must face the correct direction for mating
items.2: Retention lance (if present) must engage housing lock
items.3: Check connector housing for insertion direction guides

1.title: Position housing correctly
1.description: Orient connector housing with keyway up and insertion side facing you

2.title: Align terminal with cavity
2.description: Match terminal position with correct cavity number. Reference wiring diagram if available.

3.title: Insert terminal with firm pressure
3.description: Push terminal straight in until you hear/feel a distinct "click" indicating lock engagement

4.title: Verify retention
4.description: Gently pull wire backward. Terminal should be solidly retained and not move.

5.title: Repeat for all positions
5.description: Continue inserting terminals in correct sequence per wiring diagram

problem1.title: Problem: Terminal won't insert fully
problem1.solution: Solution: Check terminal orientation, ensure retention lance is not bent, verify correct terminal type for housing

problem2.title: Problem: Terminal inserts but doesn't lock
problem2.solution: Solution: Retention lance may be damaged. Use new terminal. Check for obstructions in housing cavity.

problem3.title: Problem: Terminal pulls out easily
problem3.solution: Solution: Terminal not fully inserted. Remove and re-insert until positive click/lock is achieved.

terminalRemoval.title: Terminal Removal (If Needed)
terminalRemoval.description: If you need to remove or reposition a terminal:

steps.1: Use proper terminal release tool designed for RAST 5 connectors
steps.2: Insert release tool alongside terminal to depress retention lance
steps.3: While holding release tool in position, gently pull wire to extract terminal
steps.4: Inspect terminal for damage before re-insertion. Replace if lance is bent or damaged.

terminalRemoval.warning: Never attempt to remove terminals with screwdrivers or other improvised tools. This can damage both the terminal and housing.

keyingVerification.title: Keying Verification
keyingVerification.description: RAST 5 connectors use mechanical keying to prevent incorrect mating:

items.1: Verify keying code matches between mating connectors
items.2: Check polarization features align correctly
items.3: Ensure pole count and pin numbering matches application wiring

1.title: Check all terminals are fully inserted
1.description: Verify each terminal is locked and no cavities are empty (unless intentionally unpopulated)

2.title: Route wires appropriately
2.description: Arrange wires to exit connector housing cleanly without sharp bends or crossovers

3.title: Apply strain relief (if applicable)
3.description: Install cable clamps, zip ties, or strain relief boots to protect wire-to-terminal interface

4.title: Install secondary locks (if present)
4.description: Some connectors have additional locking features. Ensure these are properly engaged.

items.1: • Prevents mechanical stress from transferring to crimp connection
items.2: • Protects against vibration-induced fatigue
items.3: • Maintains wire alignment and prevents pulling
items.4: • Extends service life in harsh environments

items.1: • Cable ties securing wire bundle near connector (most common)
items.2: • Connector-specific strain relief boots or clips
items.3: • Cable clamps mounted to equipment chassis
items.4: • Flexible conduit for additional protection

items.1: All terminals properly crimped and inspected
items.2: All terminals fully inserted and locked in housing
items.3: Wire routing is clean and organized
items.4: Strain relief applied appropriately
items.6: No foreign material or debris in connector

sealedConnectors.title: Sealed Connector Assembly
sealedConnectors.description: Sealed connectors provide protection against moisture, dust, and contaminants:

steps.1: Use only specified sealed terminals and wire seals for your connector model
steps.2: Install wire seal onto cable before crimping terminal (cannot be added after)
steps.3: Ensure wire seal is properly sized for cable outer diameter
steps.4: After terminal insertion, position seal against rear of connector housing
steps.5: Install connector seal/gasket if required (some models use separate housing seals)
steps.6: Verify seal integrity - no gaps, proper compression when mated

sealedConnectors.note: IP (Ingress Protection) ratings are only valid when connectors are properly mated and all seals are correctly installed. Unmated sealed connectors should be protected with dust caps.

highVibration.title: High-Vibration Applications
highVibration.description: Applications with significant vibration (automotive, industrial machinery, transportation) require additional considerations:

items.1: • Use connectors with positive locking mechanisms
items.2: • Consider connectors with secondary locks or locking clips
items.3: • Specify connectors rated for vibration resistance

items.1: • Ensure all terminals are fully locked with positive click
items.2: • Apply additional strain relief close to connector (within 50mm)
items.3: • Use flexible wire to absorb vibration before connector
items.4: • Mount connectors to rigid points, not to vibrating components
items.5: • Consider using vibration-dampening mounts or grommets

items.1: • Inspect connections regularly for signs of fretting or wear
items.2: • Check for backed-out terminals or loose connections
items.3: • Monitor contact resistance over time

temperature.title: Temperature Considerations
temperature.standardRating: Standard RAST 5 connectors are typically rated for -40°C to +105°C (-40°F to +221°F). Operating outside this range requires special considerations:

items.1: • Verify connector housing material is rated for application temperature
items.2: • Use high-temperature wire insulation (Teflon, PTFE, silicone)
items.3: • Derate current capacity per manufacturer specifications
items.4: • Consider thermal expansion effects on terminal retention

items.1: • Verify housing material remains flexible at low temperature
items.2: • Use cold-rated wire insulation that won't crack or become brittle
items.3: • Test mating/unmating forces at operating temperature
items.4: • Account for thermal contraction in tight spaces

items.1: • Repeated temperature cycles can cause fretting corrosion
items.2: • Different expansion rates between materials may affect retention
items.3: • Consider gold-plated terminals for improved reliability
items.4: • Allow stress relief in wire routing to accommodate expansion

temperature.note: Always consult manufacturer datasheets for specific temperature ratings and derating requirements. Contact your RAST 5 supplier for high-temperature or low-temperature connector options if needed.

maintenanceSchedules.title: Maintenance & Inspection Schedules
maintenanceSchedules.description: Regular inspection and maintenance extends connector service life and prevents unexpected failures:

items.1: • Visual inspection of all crimps and connections
items.2: • Continuity testing of all circuits
items.3: • Contact resistance measurement (if critical application)
items.4: • Verify proper mating and locking

items.1: • Visual inspection for physical damage or contamination
items.2: • Check for backed-out or loose terminals
items.3: • Verify locking features still engaged
items.4: • Inspect strain relief for wear or damage
items.5: • Check for signs of overheating (discoloration, melting)
items.6: • Clean contacts if necessary (per manufacturer guidelines)

items.1: • All items from periodic inspection
items.2: • Contact resistance trending
items.3: • Seal integrity verification (sealed connectors)
items.4: • Corrosion inspection
items.6: • Consider preventive replacement based on lifecycle

items.1: • Intermittent connections or circuit dropouts
items.2: • Elevated contact resistance
items.3: • Visible corrosion on contacts or terminals
items.4: • Cracked, melted, or damaged housing
items.6: • Burning smell or discoloration from heat

troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting Guide
troubleshooting.description: Solutions to common assembly problems and how to fix mistakes

problem1.title: Problem: Wire pulls out of crimped terminal

items.1: • Under-crimped terminal
items.2: • Wrong terminal size for wire gauge
items.3: • Damaged or cut wire strands

items.1: • Cut off terminal and re-crimp with new terminal
items.2: • Verify correct crimp tool and die size
items.3: • Ensure full tool closure for complete crimp
items.4: • Use fresh wire end if strands are damaged

problem2.title: Problem: Terminal won't insert into housing

items.1: • Wrong terminal type for housing
items.2: • Terminal retention lance bent or damaged
items.3: • Incorrect orientation
items.4: • Obstruction in housing cavity

items.1: • Verify terminal type matches connector specification
items.2: • Inspect retention lance - replace terminal if damaged
items.3: • Check terminal orientation guide on housing
items.4: • Inspect cavity for debris or previous terminal remnants

problem3.title: Problem: High contact resistance or intermittent connection

items.1: • Poor crimp quality (inadequate metal-to-metal contact)
items.2: • Oxidation or contamination on terminals
items.3: • Terminal not fully inserted in housing
items.4: • Damaged contact area

items.1: • Remove and replace with properly crimped terminal
items.2: • Clean contacts with electronic contact cleaner
items.3: • Verify terminal is fully locked (should hear/feel click)
items.4: • Inspect for bent or damaged contact springs
items.5: • Measure contact resistance - should be less than 5 milliohms

items.1: • Mismatched keying codes
items.2: • Bent or damaged pins/terminals
items.3: • Foreign material in connector
items.4: • Incorrect connector pairing

items.1: • Verify keying codes match (check connector markings)
items.2: • Inspect for bent pins - carefully straighten if possible
items.3: • Clean both connectors with compressed air
items.4: • Confirm connector types are compatible (check part numbers)

problem5.title: Problem: Terminal backs out after insertion

items.1: • Terminal not fully seated (incomplete insertion)
items.2: • Damaged retention lance
items.3: • Excessive wire tension or pulling
items.4: • Wrong terminal type

items.1: • Remove terminal and re-insert, ensuring positive click/lock
items.2: • Replace terminal if lance is damaged
items.3: • Add strain relief to prevent wire tension
items.4: • Verify correct terminal part number for housing
items.5: • Check that locking feature fully engages

items.1: • Excessive current for wire/terminal rating
items.2: • Poor crimp creating high resistance
items.3: • Corroded or contaminated contacts
items.4: • Loose connection

items.1: • Verify current load is within connector rating
items.2: • Replace connector and re-terminate with quality crimps
items.3: • Use larger wire gauge if current is near limit
items.4: • Check for high resistance with multimeter
items.5: • Ensure proper terminal insertion and locking
items.6: • Consider parallel circuits for high-current applications

stillHavingProblems.title: Still Having Problems?
stillHavingProblems.description: If you've tried these solutions and still experiencing issues:

items.1: • Review the complete installation guide from Step 1
items.2: • Verify you have correct components for your application
items.3: • Consult manufacturer datasheets for specific requirements
items.4: • Consider replacing all components with fresh parts

items.tools: Gathered all required tools and materials
items.safety: Read and understood all safety precautions

items.1: • IEC 60352 (Crimping)
items.2: • IEC 60603 (Connectors)
items.3: • UL 310 (Wire Terminals)
items.4: • ISO 8092 (Contact Retention)

contactSupport.title: Need Additional Help?
contactSupport.description: Our technical support team is here to assist with connector selection, installation questions, and troubleshooting.
